review_title: Great experience working for UCLA Housing
job_title: Media Team Member in Los Angeles, CA
pros: Great team resources, lots of support from managers, clear expectations, positive culture.
cons: I don't have any cons at all!

job_title: Event Manager in Los Angeles, CA
pros: Flexible hours, good benefits, no micromanagement, good food options on campus. A very stable place to work at.
cons: Low pay, too much work, too many different things to handle and service. A lot of turnover due to burnout. No room for growth. Lack of appreciation. Pay is below market average for sure.

job_title: Auditor in Los Angeles, CA
pros: Good office environment and there are coffee and tea served
cons: There is little improvement and career development

review_title: Poor Pay. Poor upper management. DO NOT LISTEN to good reviews, most student jobs. NOT FULL TIME CAREER STAFF.
job_title: Administrative Assistant in La Mirada, CA
pros: - When family emergencies happen there is flexibility. - Colleagues are friendly. Everyone is just trying to help each other get work done. - Great job if looking for stability.... so stable and stagnate that even your pay barely budges -Pension (if you are willing to devote your life to UC-system but note the severe opportunity cost of this as you can make so much more in the private sector.)
cons: - You will have two types of colleagues. Comrade-in-arms in suffering, the very definition of "TEAMWORK MAKES THE DREAM WORK". Or lazy coworkers who make your life more miserable and add to your workload. - Extremely low pay compared to market rates. Management will never give you for more than "meets expectations" in employee evaluations because if they do so, means you deserve a raise which requires approval from the top-echelons if the raise is 5% or more. Expect the only "raises" to receive your cost-of-living-adjustments. Management will try to convince you this is a raise. DO NOT BE FOOLED. When my job got unionized, it translated to the new "career-paths" pay scale which forced me up to the minimum scalling from 35% below market rate to 25%. I knew I was severely being underpaid but didn't realize how bad they were lowballing and only accepted this job in the first place a few years back due to health issues with immediate family members. All pay-data is public information so EVERYONE knows how much EVERYONE is making. - Commute is horrible. Expect to spend 2.5-3 hours a day in traffic. 10% of my pay goes to gas. Lucky if you are hybrid or remote but from the looks of it management is slowly phasing this out. Admin's answer to this? Save money by taking public transit or vanpool, you don't have to drive but now lose 4-5 hours of your day, flexibility, and not to mention if your car gets broken into at the pickup location parking spots. You've just negated whatever monetary savings. -COVID was a death sentence in the workplace. So much brain talent and experienced staff were lost from either early retirement or simply made significantly more money elsewhere. Every department is scrambling to hire... but can't fill positions because no one is going to accept the low pay, with long and expensive commute, while still paying for meals

job_title: Manager in Los Angeles, CA
pros: Benefits, great team members, being Part of a Bigger Mission, work/life balance, family-friendly
cons: non-existent leadership, career growth is difficult, no accountability for poor supervisor behavior, years of annual employee surveys that rate below 50% satisfaction, and no desire to truly fix the issues

job_title: Dispatch Supervisor in Westwood, CA
pros: flexible schedule, accommodation for student commitments
cons: change of management, hours may be long/overnight

job_title: Front-Desker in Los Angeles, CA
pros: On the campus of UCLA.
cons: Can be a bit unorganized.

job_title: Receptionist in Los Angeles, CA
pros: great atmosphere, good managers, benefits
cons: no room for growth, pay.

job_title: Assistant Manager in Los Angeles, CA
pros:
-Easy interview process 
-Discounts on UCLA Dining
cons:
-Hours are horrible - 10 am - 7 PM 
- Management has a cap on raises - anything over 5% has to be approved by the Assistant Vice Chancellor 
- Incompetent/lazy managers and workers who get away with “remote work” and “medical leaves” who don’t show up for their shifts

review_title: Student Food Service Worker at Dining Halls
job_title: Anonymous Employee in UCLA, CA
pros:
The work hours can be flexible
Working with students our age
You get free meals during your break
cons:
The management can suck
Heavy labor, including cleaning, carrying heavy food trays, and working under heat (literally made me sweat so much) depending on your assigned station.
Expected to smile at the customers all the time (ewww)

job_title: Field Operations Supervisor in Los Angeles, CA
pros:
-Managers are amazing.
-beautiful work environment 
-work can be challenging but it's always fun and rewarding
cons: Wish I could have Continued after graduating.

job_title: Front Desk Agent in Los Angeles, CA
pros:
Mostly organized
Follows labor laws
Priority housing
Summer opportunities
Meet new friends
cons:
Overnight shifts
Holiday shifts
Busy seasons
Safety
Exercising from walking hills

job_title: Audio Production Assistant in Los Angeles, CA
pros: Working with UCLA Housing as an Audio Engineer and Producer was amazing! I loved this job so much. I hope Studio 22 continues after the pandemic.
cons: The pay and work hour limit. If I had the choice I would work more than 12 hours a week.

job_title: Student Programming Assistant in UCLA, CA
pros: Flexible work period and great environment.
cons: Late night work and heavy lifting.

job_title: Student Worker in Los Angeles, CA
pros: The work is not demanding, and many of the employees are friendly.
cons: The pay is low and there are easier jobs at UCLA.

job_title: Management in Los Angeles, CA
pros: Excellent Holidays throughout the year.  Great people to work with.
cons: Pay is no where close to what's offered on the private sector. Even though there's a ton of holidays, there are some that are obligated to work those days and still remain on-call even while on vacation.

job_title: Corporate Trainer in Los Angeles, CA
pros:
- You have the opportunity to meet new and cool people
- Pay is good for the work you have to do
- Working during the school year is chill
cons:
- Can be hard to get the schedule you want if you're bottom priority
- They expect students to stand for hours at a time
- Working summer hours can be exhausting

review_title: Great Job if You Are Okay With a Government Job
job_title: Senior Database Manager in Los Angeles, CA
pros: Stability and security. Also, although you don't get compensation reviews and promotions/raises, they appear more willing to endure okay employees than the private sector.
cons: If you strive to be a super star, don't work for any organization or agency that is governed by rules instead of results!

review_title: The overall experience is professional and enjoyable

pros: All staff takes you seriously and allows you to learn the ins and outs of hospitality and management

job_title: Operations Supervisor in Los Angeles, CA

job_title: Food Service Worker in Los Angeles, CA
